source.raw_text:
The Sandbag Zercher Squat is a full-body compound movement that heavily targets the Quadriceps, Glutes, Core (abs/obliques), and Upper Back (traps/rhomboids) for strength, while also engaging Hamstrings, Biceps, and Forearms for stability and grip, all within a front-loaded squat pattern that promotes an upright torso and enhances functional strength for real-world lifting tasks. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers: Quadriceps, Glutes. 
• Stabilizers/Assisters: Core (Abdominals, Obliques), Upper Back (Traps, Erector Spinae, Rhomboids, Rear Delts). 
• Grip/Arms: Biceps, Forearms. 
• Secondary/Assist: Hamstrings. [1, 2, 3, 4]  

Movement Pattern & Key Aspects 

• Front-Loaded Squat: The weight is held in the crook of the elbows, placing the load in front of the body. Front Rack position.
• Upright Torso: This anterior loading forces a more upright posture, reducing lower back stress compared to traditional back squats. 
• Enhanced Core Stability: The unstable nature of the sandbag demands significant core engagement to prevent forward collapse. 
• Functional Strength: Mimics lifting objects from the ground, building practical strength for daily activities. 
• Full-Body Activation: Requires comprehensive muscular effort, making it a great full-body developer. [1, 2, 4, 5, 6]  

How it Works (Pattern) 

1. Setup: Lift the sandbag into the crook of your elbows. 
2. Descent: Squat down by breaking at the hips and knees, keeping your chest up and core braced, sinking below parallel. 
3. Ascent: Drive up through your heels, pushing your knees out, and squeeze your glutes at the top. 
4. Key: Maintain constant tension on the core and upper back to keep the sandbag stable and your torso upright throughout the movement. [1, 2, 7]
